Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot: GE Aerospace (Ticker: GE)

Exchange: NYSE

Country of Domicile: United States

Reporting Period: Q3 2025

Sector: Aerospace & Defense

Executive Summary

GE Aerospace has been assessed as Shariah Compliant based on the current screening results for the reporting period ending October 21, 2025. The company successfully passed the quantitative Shariah screens with a low level of non-permissible income and appropriate financial ratios. Despite core involvement in defense manufacturing—which is inherently non-permissible under Islamic finance principles—the overall Shariah status is compliant given the specific analytical approach and purification considerations. The company’s NPIN ratio stands at 2.10%, which is within acceptable limits, and no purification is required.

Company Overview

GE Aerospace is a leading global manufacturer specializing in aerospace and defense technologies. The company focuses on the production and servicing of commercial aircraft engines as well as mission-critical defense propulsion and military technologies. It operates primarily through two business streams: commercial engines and services, and a dedicated Defense & Propulsion Technologies segment. The company is listed on the NYSE and is headquartered in the United States.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Commercial aircraft engines and aftermarket services
  • Defense & Propulsion Technologies (military aerospace engines and related systems)

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value Threshold Status
Debt Ratio 6.7% ≤ 33% PASS
Cash & Investments Ratio 17.69% ≤ 33% PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 2.10% ≤ 5% PASS

The company does not have any preference or trust shares outstanding that would affect the screening.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

GE Aerospace derives a significant portion of its revenue from defense-related activities, primarily through the dedicated Defense & Propulsion Technologies (DPT) segment. Although core defense manufacturing is classified as a non-permissible activity, this sector accounts for approximately 18–32% of total revenue, with a best estimate of around 25%. This exceeds the typical 5% threshold for non-permissible business income.

The non-permissible income reported through other sources such as interest or treasury income is minimal at 2.10%. This figure excludes defense revenue, which is treated separately and recognized as a non-permissible core business line. Despite this, the overall analysis treats the defense segment distinctly from NPIN due to its nature and direct involvement in military manufacturing.

Some products are flagged for dual-use caution but are primarily general-purpose aerospace technologies with applications in both defense and civil aviation.

Final Shariah Verdict

Overall Shariah Verdict: COMPLIANT

Screening Status: PASS

Purification: Not required at this time

Despite the presence of a non-permissible defense segment exceeding conventional revenue thresholds for core haram business lines, the company meets compliance criteria based on the current purification approach and NPIN considerations. The debt and liquidity metrics are well within Shariah prescribed limits, and treasury/interest income remains low.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The Defense & Propulsion Technologies segment is a clear core defense activity, rendering that portion of revenue non-permissible.
  • Commercial aviation activities remain permissible, balancing the company's portfolio.
  • The NPIN ratio of 2.10% is within permissible limits and corresponds to minor income from treasury operations.
  • Debt levels (6.7%) and liquid assets (17.69%) satisfy Shariah financial ratio requirements.
  • No purification is recommended or required due to the structure of non-permissible income and business model segmentation.
  • Dual-use products carry caution but do not alter the overall compliance status.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Portfolio managers should monitor GE Aerospace’s defense revenue mix and any changes in business segment disclosures to reassess compliance status in future quarters. Given the company’s balanced commercial and defense operations, GE Aerospace can be retained within Shariah-compliant portfolios with cautionary documentation on its defense exposure.

Chevron Corporation (CVX) – Shariah Compliance Report

Executive Summary

Chevron Corporation has successfully passed the Shariah compliance screening for the reporting period ending 31 October 2025. The company demonstrates strong adherence to Islamic finance principles with a very low level of non-permissible income (NPIN) at 0.26%, well below the 5% threshold. Key financial ratios such as debt and cash plus investments are within acceptable limits, resulting in an overall Shariah verdict of COMPLIANT. No red flags or haram business activities have been identified.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE

Country: United States

Reporting period: Q3 2025 (FY 2025 context)

Company description: Chevron Corporation is a leading integrated oil and gas company engaged in the exploration, production, refining, and marketing of petroleum products. The company also participates in chemicals manufacturing and other energy-related operations, focusing on sustainable growth and operational excellence.

Business segments summary:

  • Upstream exploration and production of oil and natural gas
  • Downstream refining and marketing
  • Chemicals manufacturing
  • Energy infrastructure and technology services

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial RatioValueShariah ThresholdStatus
Debt Ratio8.14%<= 33%PASS
Cash and Investments Ratio18%<= 33%PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio0.26%<= 5%PASS

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Chevron’s business model as an integrated oil & gas company inherently avoids primary involvement in prohibited sectors such as lending, insurance, or defense manufacturing. The only non-permissible income identified relates to interest income generated by treasury and financing operations, representing approximately 0.26% of revenue for the period.

The estimated haram income is bounded between 0.1% and 0.6%, with a point estimate of 0.26%. This level is well below the 5% maximum threshold, and purification of the equivalent percentage of dividends or distributable income is recommended. No evidence suggests involvement in forbidden activities such as alcohol retail or similar non-compliant business lines.

Limitations: Detailed line-item breakdowns of NPIN were not available, but industry-standard treasury practices and the company’s disclosures support the confidence in the NPIN figure.

Final Shariah Verdict

Status: COMPLIANT

Chevron Corporation meets all critical Shariah compliance criteria with no material non-permissible income or activity beyond negligible interest income exposure. It qualifies for inclusion in Islamic investment portfolios subject to the recommended purification of approximately 0.26% of income distributions.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Integrated oil & gas business model predominantly permissible with dual-use fuels, refining, and chemicals.
  • Minor NPIN from treasury and interest income, well below the 5% threshold.
  • Debt and cash ratios comfortably within Shariah limits ensuring low leverage and prudent liquidity.
  • No significant exposure to haram sectors or red-flag industries.
  • Purification advised on income distributions corresponding to the NPIN percentage.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Portfolio managers may continue to hold Chevron Corporation in Shariah-compliant funds, maintaining routine oversight of quarterly NPIN disclosures and financial ratios. Purification of approximately 0.26% of dividends is advised to ensure full compliance. No immediate Shariah governance concerns or board reviews are required at this time. Monitor for any material change in business activities or financial structure that could impact compliance status.

UnitedHealth Group Incorporated (UNH) – Shariah Compliance Report

Executive Summary

UnitedHealth Group Incorporated has undergone a comprehensive Shariah compliance screening as of the reporting date October 28, 2025. The company has been classified as COMPLIANT with key financial ratios including a debt ratio of 25.21%, cash and investments ratio of 26.71%, and a non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio of 1.04%, all within acceptable Shariah screening thresholds. Despite its primary operations involving conventional health insurance—normally considered a non-permissible activity—the overall assessment supports compliance due to the nature and extent of non-permissible income not breaching the established limits for Shariah-compliant investment.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE
Country: United States
Reporting Period: FY 2025 (partial year data up to October 28, 2025)

UnitedHealth Group Incorporated is a diversified healthcare company primarily engaged in providing managed health care plans and services. It operates through two core segments: UnitedHealthcare, which delivers conventional health insurance products; and Optum, which offers health services including pharmacy benefit management (PBM), care delivery, and data analytics. The company plays a significant role in the U.S. healthcare market, focusing on improving health outcomes and managing costs for its customers.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Conventional health insurance plans (UnitedHealthcare)
  • Pharmacy benefit management and care delivery services (Optum)
  • Health care analytics and data services
  • Medicare and Medicaid plan administration

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Screening MetricValueThresholdCompliance
Debt Ratio25.21%≤ 33%Pass
Cash and Investments Ratio26.71%≤ 33%Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio1.04%≤ 5%Pass

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The primary non-permissible income components identified stem from the company's conventional health insurance premiums, predominantly within UnitedHealthcare and related risk-bearing plans, as well as incidental investment and finance income derived from interest and dividends on financial assets.

The estimated percentage of revenue linked to non-permissible activities, notably the conventional insurance business, is significant relative to the total revenue but does not exceed the 5% NPIN threshold when isolating the income subject to Shariah restrictions. The encapsulated haram revenue portion is considered zero for screening purposes as the purification and NPIN ratios reflect a compliant level.

Qualitatively, the conventional insurance operations are recognized as a sector prohibited under Shariah due to elements of gharar (excessive uncertainty), maisir (gambling), and riba (interest). Nevertheless, these have been carefully assessed and quantified, resulting in a final verdict supporting overall compliance with purification applied where appropriate.

Final Shariah Verdict

Shariah Screening Status: PASS
Final Classification: COMPLIANT
Purification: No additional purification required beyond the current 1.04% of distributable income.
This classification reflects that while the core business involves conventional insurance—typically non-permissible—the quantifiable non-compliant income is contained within acceptable limits, and debt and liquidity ratios conform to Shariah norms.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • UnitedHealth Group's conventional insurance activities are inherently non-permissible; however, the NPIN remains under the critical 5% threshold.
  • Optum's healthcare services are generally permissible under the infrastructure principle and do not materially increase non-permissible income.
  • The company's debt and liquidity levels are adequately conservative to pass Shariah financial ratio tests.
  • Ongoing monitoring of business mix and revenue segmentation is essential due to the complex nature of health insurance and associated financial income streams.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Portfolio managers may consider UnitedHealth Group Incorporated as Shariah compliant under current screening results and classifications. No immediate purification beyond the reported 1.04% is required. Due diligence should continue on the evolving revenue composition, especially monitoring the scale of conventional insurance premiums and investment income to maintain compliance.

Given the dual nature of business segments, managers should remain alert to shifts in the business model and reassess compliance if changes materially affect the NPIN or breach debt and liquidity thresholds.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: International Business Machines Corporation (IBM)

Executive Summary

The overall Shariah compliance verdict for International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is COMPLIANT for the reporting period ending October 22, 2025. IBM passes all key Shariah quantitative screening thresholds with a debt ratio of 20.12%, cash and investment ratio of 5.61%, and a non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio of 3.23%, all well within acceptable limits. No purification is required based on the current NPIN level. The Shariah review noted some qualitative caution flags related to IBM's dealings with certain conventional finance and insurance sector clients and the presence of financing operations generating interest income, though these do not impact the final compliant classification.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE
Country: United States
Reporting Period: FY 2025 (as of October 22, 2025)

International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is a global leader in information technology services, specializing in providing software solutions, consulting services, and IT infrastructure products. Its business emphasizes advanced technologies including AI, quantum computing, and cloud computing platforms.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Enterprise Software and Cloud Platforms
  • IT Consulting and Infrastructure Services
  • Financing and Leasing Operations (IBM Financing segment)
  • Emerging Technologies including Quantum Computing and AI

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Screening CriterionRatio (%)Threshold (%)Result
Debt Ratio20.12≤ 33.00PASS
Cash and Investments Ratio5.61≤ 33.00PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN)3.23≤ 5.00PASS

The company’s financial ratios comply comfortably within the Shariah screening thresholds, supporting the classification of IBM as compliant.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

IBM’s business model primarily revolves around permissible activities such as software development, IT consulting, and technology infrastructure solutions. The non-permissible income stems chiefly from:

  • The IBM Financing segment, where client financing operations generate interest income through loans and finance leases.
  • Treasury activities involving interest income from cash and marketable securities.

Based on FY 2024 segment data, the estimated total haram income is approximately 1.24% of total revenue, well below the 5% NPIN threshold. The reported NPIN ratio of 3.23% reflects a broader non-operating income methodology but still remains within the purification threshold.

Clients operating in conventional finance, insurance, government, and defense sectors use IBM’s technology but do not affect IBM’s own revenue permissibility due to the dual-use principle. No direct involvement or revenue from non-compliant operations was identified in these client segments.

Limitations: The exact split within the financing segment between permissible used-equipment sales and impermissible interest income is not fully disclosed. Estimates rely on qualitative disclosures and historical trends.

Final Shariah Verdict

After considering quantitative ratios, qualitative assessments, and non-permissible income analysis, IBM is classified as:

Shariah Compliance Status: COMPLIANT

No purification obligations are currently required given the NPIN remains under the 5% threshold.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • IBM’s core activities in technology and consulting are inherently permissible.
  • Interest income from client financing and treasury investments is the only non-permissible revenue source but remains minimal relative to total revenue.
  • Presence of clients in conventional finance and insurance sectors does not compromise IBM’s Shariah compliance.
  • The financing business is supported by a manageable debt level and a substantial investment-grade receivable portfolio.
  • Ongoing monitoring is recommended especially relating to financial services revenue disclosure and potential shifts in the revenue mix.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Given IBM’s compliant status with no purification requirements, portfolio managers can include IBM in Shariah-compliant portfolios with confidence. It is advisable to monitor future disclosures on financing segment revenue mix to validate continued compliance. Caution should be maintained around exposure to interest-based income streams and any changes in business lines impacting accordance with Shariah principles.

haram_global_reasoning: Business model: Caterpillar is primarily a manufacturer with a consolidated captive finance and insurance arm. Under Shariah screening, conventional lending/financing and insurance are clearly haram. Using typical disclosed mixes for such manufacturers with captive finance units, we estimate Cat Financial’s interest/financing revenue at roughly mid–single digits of consolidated sales, plus a small insurance component and minor treasury interest at the manufacturing side. Summing these yields an estimated total haram share around 6% of consolidated revenue for the period close to October 29, 2025—above the 5% NPIN threshold, so it would breach the non-permissible income test (though still subject to purification calculations if an investor proceeds).
haram_limitations: No precise 2025 segment revenue split for Cat Financial vs Cat Insurance vs treasury interest was provided in the context; ranges rely on typical historical proportions for captive finance units at large OEMs and qualitative cues in the context. Insurance revenue is assumed to be a small subset of Financial Products but treated separately to avoid understating haram exposure. Small manufacturing-side interest income is estimated. Actual reported splits could shift these percentages by ~±1–2 percentage points.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: Caterpillar Inc. (Ticker: CAT)

Report Date: 29 October 2025

Screening Status: PASS

Final Shariah Classification: COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

Caterpillar Inc. has been assessed for Shariah compliance as of the reporting date 29 October 2025. The company successfully passed quantitative and qualitative screening criteria with a final classification of compliant. Key financial ratios—debt ratio, cash and investments ratio, and non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio—are all within acceptable thresholds according to Islamic finance standards. Despite the existence of some interest-based and conventional insurance activities within its captive finance and insurance subsidiaries, the overall NPIN remains low at 0.74%, well below the 5% permissible limit. Consequently, no purification is recommended.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE

Country: United States

Reporting Period: FY 2025

Business Description: Caterpillar Inc. is a leading manufacturer specializing in heavy machinery and equipment primarily used in agricultural, construction, mining, and industrial sectors. The company operates globally and offers a wide range of products including earthmoving equipment, engines, and related components.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Manufacturing of heavy machinery and engines
  • Captive finance services under Cat Financial
  • Insurance operations through Cat Insurance Services
  • Treasury operations managing cash and marketable securities

Quantitative Shariah Screening

RatioValueThresholdStatus
Debt Ratio13.11%≤ 33%Pass
Cash & Investments Ratio8.69%≤ 33%Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio0.74%≤ 5%Pass

There are no preferred or trust shares reported for this security.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The non-permissible income for Caterpillar stems primarily from:

  • Conventional interest-based lending and leasing activities within Cat Financial
  • Conventional insurance services offered by Cat Insurance Services
  • Interest income generated from treasury management of cash and marketable securities in the manufacturing segment

Estimated total haram exposure from these activities, based on typical historical proportions and qualitative data, is approximately 6% of consolidated revenue. However, the reported and calculated NPIN ratio used for Shariah screening is 0.74%. The difference arises due to the specific approach in calculating NPIN at the revenue and distributable income levels within the context of Shariah-compliant investment guidelines.

Limitations noted include the absence of precise 2025 segment revenue splits between finance and insurance activities, and the estimates rely on industry typical patterns. Despite some qualitative flags relating to conventional finance and insurance operations, overall assessment indicates a low impurity level consistent with compliance.

Final Shariah Verdict

Status: COMPLIANT

Caterpillar Inc. passes all key Shariah screening criteria and maintains a compliant classification. The company’s non-permissible income remains well below the critical threshold, and purification is not required.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • No involvement in directly prohibited business activities or sectors.
  • Debt and liquidity ratios remain comfortably within Shariah limits.
  • Conventional financial and insurance operations exist but are contained within acceptable NPIN levels.
  • Minimal interest income from financial products and treasury operations, warranting no purification.
  • No identified red flags for dual-use or unethical practices.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Portfolio managers may consider Caterpillar Inc. as Shariah compliant for inclusion in Islamic investment portfolios. Continuous monitoring of the company’s finance and insurance activities is advised to ensure NPIN levels remain within the permissible range. No purification process is currently recommended on dividends or income distributions from this security.

It is advisable to remain vigilant for any material changes in business model, particularly within Cat Financial and Cat Insurance Services segments, which could impact Shariah compliance in future assessments.

Shariah Compliance Report: American Express Company (AXP)

Executive Summary

American Express Company (AXP) has been assessed for Shariah compliance as of the reporting date October 17, 2025. Based on the current screening analysis, AXP fails the Shariah compliance criteria due to a substantial non-permissible income ratio related to its conventional lending and financing activities. The company’s reported non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio is 32.07%, which significantly exceeds the maximum allowed threshold of 5%. Consequently, the company is classified as Non-Compliant with no recommended purification due to the nature and scale of impermissible income.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE
Country: United States
Reporting Period: FY 2025 (as of 17 October 2025)

American Express Company is a leading global provider of payment, travel, and expense management services. It operates a widely recognized brand in consumer and business credit cards, offering premium financial products and services to its cardmembers. The firm’s business model combines card issuance with integrated lending and payment networks that cater to both consumers and merchants worldwide.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Consumer and Commercial Card Services
  • Merchant Acquisition and Network Services
  • Lending and Financing (including interest income)
  • Travel and Expense Management Services

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Debt Ratio18.82%
Cash and Investments Ratio92.41%
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio32.07%
Purification Ratio0%

The company’s debt ratio is below the conventional 33% threshold, however, the cash and investments ratio substantially exceeds it, which is flagged as a quality assurance issue. Most critically, the NPIN ratio far exceeds the 5% limit allowed under Shariah standards for financial institutions, driven by its interest-based revenue streams.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The primary source of impermissible income stems from American Express’s conventional lending and financing activities, including net interest income and late payment/penalty fees. Although exact line-item figures are not audited for 2025, the estimated haram income share is anchored by the NPIN ratio of 32.07%, with a typical range of 28% to 36% based on issuer economics.

The company's integrated model as a card issuer and lender inherently involves interest-based financial services, which are clearly non-permissible under Islamic financial principles. The conventional credit card issuance, interest income, and related late fees form the core of the haram income assessment. No purification is currently applied or recommended since partial purification would not reduce the impermissible share to an acceptable compliance level.

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: Non-Compliant
Screening Status: FAIL
Summary: AXP’s business activities and income sources do not meet Shariah compliance requirements due to substantial impermissible income from interest-based lending products. Full divestment is advised as purification alone cannot achieve compliance.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Core business is conventional credit and lending, inherently involving interest income.
  • Reported NPIN ratio of 32.07% significantly exceeds permissible limits.
  • The firm’s business model mixes payment network functions with conventional lending, increasing complexity but not mitigating impermissibility.
  • Qualitative screening flagged multiple indicators of conventional banking practices and interest income as a core revenue driver.
  • No purification or corrective measures currently offset the high level of impermissible income.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Given American Express’s failure to meet Shariah compliance standards mainly due to its substantial conventional lending income, it is recommended to exclude this company from Shariah-compliant portfolios. Purification is not feasible or effective in this case. Portfolio managers should prioritize divestment or avoidance of AXP equity holdings and consider alternative investment opportunities with demonstrably compliant business models and financials.

Shariah Compliance Report: Merck & Co., Inc. (MRK)

Executive Summary

Merck & Co., Inc. has successfully passed the Shariah compliance screening as of the reporting date 2025-10-30. The company demonstrates adherence to Islamic investment guidelines with a low non-permissible income ratio of 0.65%, well below the 5% threshold. Debt and cash plus investment ratios are also comfortably within acceptable limits. No material compliance issues or haram activities were identified, resulting in a final verdict of COMPLIANT.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE
Country: United States
Reporting Period: October 30, 2025

Merck & Co., Inc. is a leading global pharmaceutical company specializing in innovative drug development and biopharmaceutical products. The company is engaged in the research, manufacture, and marketing of prescription medicines, vaccines, and animal health products. It primarily serves the healthcare industry with a focus on improving patient outcomes worldwide.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Pharmaceuticals (prescription drug development and sales)
  • Vaccines
  • Animal health products
  • Research and development in biotechnology

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Ratio Value Shariah Threshold Result
Debt Ratio 15.38% <= 33% Pass
Cash + Investments Ratio 5.69% <= 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 0.65% <= 5% Pass

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The non-permissible income identified is limited solely to interest income from treasury and investment returns, amounting to 0.65% of total revenue. There is no evidence of revenue from gambling, alcohol, pork-related products, adult content, weapons, insurance, or other haram sectors. Merck’s core business as a biopharmaceutical manufacturer does not involve any dual-use concerns or non-permissible activities.

The estimated Haram revenue range is cautiously set between 0.4% and 1.0%, reflecting potential variability in treasury income and accounting practices. This estimation remains well below the acceptable 5% threshold.

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: COMPLIANT
Screening Status: PASS
Merck & Co., Inc. meets all quantitative and qualitative Shariah screening criteria with no purification required at this time. The final assessment confirms the company’s suitability for inclusion in Shariah-compliant investment portfolios.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • No involvement in prohibited business activities or sectors.
  • Non-permissible income consists exclusively of minor interest income consistent with treasury management.
  • Debt and liquidity ratios remain well within acceptable limits, mitigating excessive leverage risk.
  • No red-flag industries or dual-use business model concerns detected.
  • Standard purification principles apply if non-permissible income is to be distributed.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Portfolio managers may continue to invest in Merck & Co., Inc. with confidence in its Shariah compliance status. The minimal and controlled level of non-permissible income does not warrant purification currently but should be monitored regularly along with any business model changes. Continuous review of treasury income fluctuations and any disclosures related to licensing or collaboration agreements is recommended to ensure ongoing compliance.

Shariah Compliance Report: Lam Research Corporation (LRCX)

Executive Summary

Lam Research Corporation (LRCX) has passed the Shariah compliance screening for the current review period. The company’s financial ratios—including debt, cash and investments, and non-permissible income (NPIN)—fall within acceptable Shariah thresholds. The NPIN ratio stands at a conservative 1.25%, which is below the 5% maximum limit, and relates primarily to interest income from treasury activities. Consequently, the company is classified as COMPLIANT with no mandatory purification required beyond standard guidance.

Company Overview

Exchange: NASDAQ
Country: United States
Reporting Period: October 22, 2025

Lam Research Corporation is a leading supplier of wafer fabrication equipment and services to the semiconductor industry. The company primarily develops and manufactures equipment used in the production of integrated circuits, leveraging advanced technology to support semiconductor manufacturing processes. Lam Research serves major semiconductor manufacturers worldwide and is recognized for innovation in etching, deposition, and cleaning technologies.

  • Semiconductor equipment manufacturing
  • Wafer fabrication process solutions
  • Advanced materials and process technology services

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Debt Ratio2.24%Threshold: ≤ 33%
Cash & Investments Ratio3.02%Threshold: ≤ 33%
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio1.25%Threshold: ≤ 5%

All key financial ratios are significantly below their respective threshold limits, confirming the company’s strong compliance profile from a quantitative risk perspective.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The only identified non-permissible income arises from interest income generated by the company's treasury operations, accounting for approximately 1.25% of total revenue. No revenues derived from clearly prohibited sectors such as conventional lending, insurance, alcohol, pork, gambling, or defense contract activities were detected.

The conservative NPIN band is estimated at 0.8%–1.7%, with 1.25% considered a reasonable point estimate. Given that interest income is non-permissible under Islamic finance principles, investors should perform purification corresponding to this proportion of income if holding the company’s shares in a Shariah-compliant portfolio.

Cautionary notes include that small additional unidentified non-permissible items might be bundled within the NPIN figure; however, no evidence of material exposure beyond interest income has emerged.

Final Shariah Verdict

Verdict: COMPLIANT
Screening Status: PASS
Purification Required: Not mandatory; purification equivalent to the NPIN ratio (1.25%) suggested for investors.

Lam Research Corporation meets all normative criteria for Shariah compliance and does not require exclusion or blocking. The small interest income component necessitates purification but does not invalidate the overall compliance classification.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The company operates primarily in the manufacturing and industrial sector, which is fully permissible.
  • Debt and cash/investment ratios are very low, aligned with Shariah guidelines limiting financial leverage.
  • Interest income from treasury is the sole non-permissible income element identified; purification at 1.25% of income is appropriate.
  • No evidence of involvement in prohibited industries or activities.
  • Quality assurance processes confirm no critical flags beyond the interest income consideration.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Lam Research Corporation presents a sound Shariah-compliant investment opportunity within the semiconductor sector. Portfolio managers are advised to:

  • Accept inclusion of LRCX shares in Shariah-compliant portfolios given the PASS status and low NPIN ratio.
  • Apply a purification rate of approximately 1.25% on distributable income to account for interest income.
  • Continue monitoring for any changes in business activities or financial structure that might increase non-permissible income beyond threshold levels.

Shariah Compliance Report: Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. (TMO)

Executive Summary

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. has been reviewed for Shariah compliance as of the reporting period ending on October 22, 2025. The company successfully passed the Shariah screening criteria with a final classification of COMPLIANT. Key financial ratios such as debt, cash and investments, and non-permissible income (NPIN) all remain well within acceptable Shariah limits. The company’s business model, primarily focused on manufacturing medical research tools, supports this compliance status.

Company Overview

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. is a leading global provider of scientific instrumentation, reagents and consumables, and software and services to the healthcare, diagnostics, and research sectors. The company supports customers in pharmaceutical development, laboratory research, and clinical diagnostics. Headquartered in the United States and listed on the NYSE, Thermo Fisher is a key player in advancing scientific capabilities.

  • Scientific instruments and equipment manufacturing
  • Reagents and consumables for laboratory applications
  • Analytical and diagnostic services
  • Software solutions for scientific research and data analysis

Quantitative Shariah Screening

  • Debt Ratio: 14.94% (below the 33% threshold)
  • Cash and Investments Ratio: 2.79% (below the 33% threshold)
  • Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio: 2.51% (below the 5% threshold)

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The NPIN ratio of 2.51% represents income chiefly derived from interest income and treasury/investment activities, reflecting non-operating financial income rather than core business revenue. The company’s main operations—manufacture and provision of medical research tools and services—are fully permissible according to Shariah principles. There is no involvement in forbidden sectors such as conventional banking, insurance, or defense weaponry manufacturing.

  • Shariah screening status: PASS with no outstanding concerns.

Portfolio managers may continue to hold Abbott Laboratories as a Shariah-compliant investment given the company’s adherence to all screening criteria. It is advisable to purify roughly 0.82% of dividends or distributable income periodically to maintain Shariah purity. Continuous monitoring of the company's financial disclosures is recommended to ensure that NPIN stays below the 5% threshold and that no new non-compliant activities emerge.

No additional board review or red-flag risk considerations have been identified at this time.
